I‚Äôm getting a lot of questions about trimming $RKLB and the answer is I‚Äôm not.

This is the second source of the space economy and we are still in the earliest innings of figuring out how big the space economy actually becomes.

When something works this well, the instinct is to protect gains especially when you‚Äôre up ~15x and it‚Äôs grown into a large position but that instinct is usually driven by fear since one of the hardest parts of growth investing is sitting through volatility after you‚Äôre already "right" because every pullback feels like a mistake for not locking it in.

Selling early often produces worse outcomes than holding through noise particularly in industries that take a decade to fully reveal themselves. Just ask early $NVDA, $TSLA or $PLTR investors. Space is one of those industries and nobody truly knows how big it gets. 

I‚Äôm comfortable being uncomfortable and I‚Äôd rather live with drawdowns than cut exposure to a ~$50B company that I believe is still in the early phase of a multi-trillion-dollar space economy.

Nvidia $NVDA says its upcoming Vera Rubin NVL72 rack will provide 260TB/s of bandwidth, or more than the entire internet.

Data centers investments are projected to reach at least $3 trillion over the next five years, per Moody‚Äôs, primarily flowing to servers, IT equipment, data center facilities and new power capacity.

$NVDA $AMD $MSFT $META $GOOG $AMZN

China is reportedly preparing to approve some $NVDA H200 imports as early as this quarter for select commercial use, though sources say it will remain banned from military, government, and state-owned enterprises.

Bernstein estimates that blended DRAM pricing including HBM will rise nearly 30% QoQ in Q4 and more than 20% QoQ in Q1, before softening to ~15% QoQ in Q2 2026.
